Key Findings

  • Customer Services & E-Government consumes £20,044,073.14—nearly 30 pence of every pound spent by the council.
  • The top three departments (Customer Services, Finance & Property, and Regeneration) control £42.1 million, or 62.5% of the entire £67.3 million budget.
  • Administrative and support functions (Customer Services, Finance, and Corporate Management) account for £39.2 million (58.3%), raising questions about the balance between back-office costs and frontline service delivery.
  • Regeneration receives £10,897,526.85 (16.2%), dwarfing traditional frontline services such as Planning Services at £1,291,790.63 (1.9%) and Communities at £1,152,499.93 (1.7%).
  • Covid-related expenditure remains on the books at £2,052,636.73 across the five-year period, despite the pandemic emergency phase concluding within this timeframe.

The Digital-First Dominance

Rossendale Borough Council's spending data reveals a local authority undergoing profound digital transformation—at considerable cost. Between 2021/22 and 2025/26, the council allocated £20,044,073.14 to Customer Services & E-Government, representing 29.8% of its total £67,293,350.95 expenditure.

This allocation makes Customer Services the single largest departmental budget, surpassing even the combined total of Planning Services, Communities, Legal & Democratic Services, and Non-Distributed Costs. While this figure encompasses critical safety-net services including revenues and benefits administration, housing advice, and digital service provision, its scale invites scrutiny. For every £100 spent by Rossendale, nearly £30 flows to this single department—a proportion that exceeds the entire regeneration budget by almost double.
